confluences.name: Niger Delta
confluences.narrative: The Niger Delta region represents one of the most significant source zones for African diasporic dance traditions. Here, ritual dances accompanying Yoruba Orisha worship, Igbo ceremonial movements, and Ijaw masquerade traditions developed in proximity, creating a complex web of influence and exchange. When the transatlantic slave trade forcibly dispersed millions of people from this region, they carried these movement vocabularies with them—to Brazil, Cuba, Haiti, and beyond. Today, we can trace echoes of Niger Delta dance in Candomblé terreiros in Salvador, in Santería ceremonies in Havana, and in Vodou rituals in Port-au-Prince.

confluences.name: Casamance
confluences.narrative: The Casamance region of southern Senegal, separated from the rest of the country by The Gambia, developed distinct dance traditions influenced by its relative isolation and the persistence of indigenous religious practices. The Jola people's initiation dances, particularly those associated with masked figures like Kumpo, represent some of the most resilient movement traditions in West Africa. GMR's lab work in Casamance focuses on documenting these dances and understanding how they connect to broader Senegambian and Atlantic world traditions.

confluences.name: Salvador da Bahia
confluences.narrative: Salvador da Bahia received more enslaved Africans than any other city in the Americas. The result was a remarkable preservation and transformation of West African movement traditions, particularly those associated with Yoruba Orisha worship. In the Candomblé houses of Bahia, dances for Xangô, Oxum, and Ogum maintain clear kinesthetic connections to their Nigerian origins—yet they have also evolved in dialogue with Indigenous Brazilian and European influences. Salvador is a critical site for understanding how diasporic dance maintains fidelity while adapting to new contexts.

confluences.name: Havana
confluences.narrative: Cuba's proximity to the United States made it a crucial node in the global circulation of African-derived dance. Havana's Santería traditions preserve elaborate choreographies for the Orishas, while secular forms like rumba developed in the city's solares and dockyards. The Cuban revolution created both challenges and opportunities for documentation—many practitioners left for Miami and New York, spreading these traditions further while the island's archives remained relatively closed. GMR is working to connect Cuban collections with their West African sources.

confluences.name: Port-au-Prince
confluences.narrative: Haiti's revolutionary history—the only successful slave revolt to create an independent nation—also preserved one of the richest repositories of African-derived movement in the Americas. Vodou ceremonies maintain dances for the lwa (spirits) that show clear connections to Fon and Ewe traditions from present-day Benin and Togo. The yanvalou, a signature Vodou movement pattern, provides a fascinating case study in how a specific kinesthetic vocabulary can persist across centuries of separation.

confluences.name: New Orleans
confluences.narrative: New Orleans occupies a unique position in the African diasporic dance network. Congo Square provided a rare legal space for enslaved Africans to gather and dance, creating a documented record of movement practices that were suppressed elsewhere in North America. The city's ongoing second line tradition, brass band funerals, and Mardi Gras Indian practices represent living continuations of African-derived movement, transformed through centuries of creolization.

confluences.name: Kingston
confluences.narrative: Jamaica's dance traditions span from the sacred movements of Kumina—preserving Kongo cosmological ideas—to the global phenomenon of dancehall. Kingston serves as both an archive of retention and an engine of innovation. GMR is particularly interested in tracing connections between Jamaican dance and its West African sources, as well as understanding how contemporary Jamaican movement vocabulary circulates globally through digital media.

confluences.name: Accra
confluences.narrative: Ghana's position as a major departure point for the transatlantic slave trade makes it essential to any study of diasporic dance. Accra and its surroundings host diverse traditions—the Ga people's kpanlogo developed in the 1960s as a conscious blend of traditional and popular influences, while older forms like adowa maintain ceremonial significance. Ghana has also become a destination for diaspora 'returnees,' creating feedback loops as African Americans and Afro-Caribbeans bring back transformed versions of movements that originated here.
